title: 108_hr3645
content: "Section 1. Essential Fish Habitat." The definition of essential fish habitat under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to include marine waters and benthic structures crucial for fish spawning and breeding. Measures are also included to minimize adverse impacts on essential fish habitat. The definition of essential fish habitat under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to include marine waters and benthic structures crucial for fish spawning and breeding, with measures to minimize adverse effects on essential fish habitat caused by fishing. SEC. 2. DURATION OF MEASURES TO REBUILD OVERFISHED FISHERIES. Section 304(e)(4)(A)(ii) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to allow for an extension of the 10-year rebuilding period in cases where the cause of fishery decline is outside the jurisdiction of the Council or the Secretary. The rebuilding program's effectiveness may require more than just limiting fishing activities. The Secretary can extend the 10-year rebuilding period for overfished components of a multi-species fishery. SEC. 3. COMPLIANCE WITH NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT OF 1969. This section amends the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act to ensure that any fishery management plan or regulation prepared in accordance with the Act complies with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. SEC. 4. BERING SEA AND ALEUTIAN ISLAND CRAB RATIONALIZATION PROGRAM ADJUSTMENT. Transition to sustainable fisheries by ensuring compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands Crab Rationalization Program is amended to allocate 1.5 percent of crab processing quota shares to Blue Dutch, LLC for various fisheries. Regulations will also reduce quota shares for other holders to maintain balance. The allocation of "Class A" crab processing quota shares for certain fisheries equals 90 percent of the total allowable catch. SEC. 5. ALASKA COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT QUOTA PROGRAM. Eligibility for participation in the program is granted to approved communities, with the possibility of additional communities meeting criteria in the future. Allocation adjustments are made under Section 206(a) of Public Law 105-277. SEC. 6. REPORT REGARDING TREATMENT OF INTERNATIONAL FISHERY COMMISSION PENSIONERS. The President is required to determine the number of US citizens who worked for specific international fishery commissions in Canada, calculate the difference in annuity payments between US and Canadian currency for each employee, and submit a report to the House of Representatives Committee on Resources by September 1, 2004. The President must determine the number of US citizens working for international fishery commissions in Canada, calculate the difference in annuity payments between US and Canadian currency for each employee, and submit a report to the House of Representatives Committee on Resources and the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation.
